card.name: PaC Spike: Flow 1 - Find material in repo

data.text: @arvind_sv in regards to the second point, I agree. The diagram does a poor job of showing that the circles represent background actions so the user would be on the material screen during this time and therefore progress should be shown

card.name: PaC Spike: Flow 1 - Find material in repo

data.text:
Here are my thoughts from Slack: https://twstudios.slack.com/archives/CHCEGDBSA/p1559071056009300?thread_ts=1558719804.003000&cid=CHCEGDBSA

- Prefer to not have: “Includes pipeline config”. A magical user experience is that it is found automatically. How about:
 1. They enter a material URL.
 2. We try to clone it and find out and show a message: “We found a pipeline config in your repo. Do you want us to use that ... ?”
 3. If not, and it takes more than 5 seconds or is too big a repo for us to shallow clone from, then we show a message: “We couldn’t clone the repo, do you have a pipeline config that you’d like us to use?”

- When in the “Add config repo (inferring details) parse config” part, it would be good to show progress to a user.

/cc @steven_st

card.name: Chat crazyegg heatmap

data.text: @kiera_radman @lpena Until we get better tracking set up for these CTAs I'd rather not make that total assumption, but it would appear that there is some discrepancy there. On major thing to note: Crazyegg ONLY captures data for the first 20 seconds of a users interaction with the page, which means that we are missing a part of the picture here.

card.name: Chat crazyegg heatmap

data.text: @lpena am I understanding this correctly, that most people navigate away from the page?  It seems odd that there is almost nothing on the download buttons (unless I'm blind), yet the "heat" on either side of the command "./run-gocd" indicates to me that people may be copy/pasting this command

card.name: Chat crazyegg heatmap

data.text: My hypothesis is that users may be scared off by the 'not for production' text. My reasoning behind this is that I see indications of people reading with their mouse (light blue hovers that follow the lines of text) over this paragraph, and then a significant amount of mouse activity over the 'setting up your gocd server' at the bottom.

card.name: Validate empty pipeline group

data.text:
I don't think having an empty pipeline group makes the user more or less likely to add a pipeline at this point in the journey. The intention of the design is for a new user to not accidentally associate the pipeline they are about to create as being connected in any way to the example pipelines that we provide. Despite the fact that the spatial relationship of the pipelines on the pipeline group page have no bearing on whether or not they are connected, I saw indicators in our research that new users might mistakenly make that association, and that is not the experience we would like them to have.

@kiera_radman @loudapena We can chat about this on Monday if you'd like.

Verified on 
GoCD Version: 19.5.0 (9261-c66edbe5b77511d884d7e5d889708ea63bdc9253)

card.name: Auto trigger component (stage)

data.text:
Context: this component’s style (or lack thereof) feels out of place compared to other form inputs.

It should be styled so the product feels polished.

An alternative to this control could be a switch, for which we already have a styled component. This could work as the choice is binary anyway.

However, I would word this differently if choosing the switch approach as a switch provides an on-off concept: “Automatically run this stage after updates?”

card.name: Create empty pipeline group only for trial

data.text:
Looked into this a bit - at the surface, seems straightforward.

First rock I tripped over: group permissions. The dashboard api needs permissions for each group and that is calculated from it child pipelines. I believe this is a solved problem though - choosing a sensible set of permissions based on more top-level configs. We seem to do this in part already in other places

card.name: development of add pipeline page

data.text: @steven_st is it possible to get the concept diagrams with the surrounding white space trimmed? The prototype diagrams were hacked to used the svg images as backgrounds so I could clip, scale and reposition to remove all that, but required customizing all those attrs per image to get it right. Going forward, it would be more maintainable if the images didn’t need that level of customization to be usable. Not extremely urgent as I’ve done those calculations already, but it would make everything simpler to implement, esp if we continue to change the diagrams.

card.name: Save and Run + Save and Edit components

data.text: Just to be clear for anyone picking up this work, I believe the decision at the moment is to include both options.

card.name: Save and Run + Save and Edit components

data.text:
We can talk. Let me know which meeting I need to attend. About this decision, consider the case when a user has gone past a trial. What is their experience? They now know a pipeline can have multiple materials, stages, jobs, etc. How do they create a pipeline with that?

1. Create pipeline with one material, stage, job.
2. Save and run.
3. Cancel the build.
4. Edit pipeline.
5. Save.
6. Come back to dashboard and run.

card.name: Save and Run + Save and Edit components

data.text: @loudapena @marquesfarques @arvind_sv I feel like this is a discussion we should be having not in a trello card comment, since it is a nuanced decision. Can we chat about it as a group in our meeting on monday?

card.name: Save and Run + Save and Edit components

data.text: @steven_st @marquesfarques @arvind_sv What is the reasoning? We don't seem to have much evidence that folks would really head in this direction. The positive side of not having it is that we offer a streamlined experience for him that has appeared over many interviews to be the path of choice. I believe the reason we had the two options was due to making a big change to the actual product itself.

card.name: Save and Run + Save and Edit components

data.text: @marquesfarques @loudapena @arvind_sv I think we should still keep save an edit as the secondary option.

card.name: Save and Run + Save and Edit components

data.text:
@loudapena :thumbsup:

I think we can get away without "Save + Edit" because I suspect people generally build a pipeline in a piecemeal fashion, rather than all at once. So I hypothesize that people would start with something relatively simple, save to see that it's right, then click the gear icon to continue tinkering. I also could be completely wrong :). @arvind_sv what do you think?

card.name: Save and Run + Save and Edit components

data.text: @marquesfarques My preference of keeping it simple may conflict with what needs to live in the product. Let's check with Duck on this to see if it's necessary. If it is not necessary, I think keeping it to Save+Run is not only the most intuitive, but the most common next step our users want to take. Consistently they all felt running it was the best thing to do to see if their pipeline worked. They wanted any additional configuration to take place after that had run.

card.name: Revisit copy in terminal to make sure expectations are clear

data.text: @ibnc2 We definitely saw that as a confusing message the first time around. I think your suggestion makes a lot of sense. I'd prefer for them to know that they have to wait for that button to load instead of being mislead by the terminal message. I don't want them to stray too far of the journey, so if we tell them to go somewhere it should probably be something like "... you can read about GoCD concepts while your server loads...." et al. What do you think?

card.name: Revisit copy in terminal to make sure expectations are clear

data.text: @loudapena I was thinking that the messaging around "you may use GoCD server at: ..." could be changed. It sort of implies that the server has completely started when it's not actually fully started. I was think something around the lines of "While you wait for the server to fully start, you can go here: link" or something along those lines. Thoughts?

card.name: Revisit copy in terminal to make sure expectations are clear

data.text: @loudapena gotcha. I'll use my best judgement :)

card.name: Revisit copy in terminal to make sure expectations are clear

data.text: @ibnc2 Sure, we know the copy was a bit rough just to get the testing version out, and that what was provided in the terminal could be polished. I don't have much more clarification for you on that, but we should ensure that what is there makes sense to the user, that any URLs are correct and that all formatting is polished. I can help with any editing, but I think since a lot of this is meant to be read by developers it may make sense to run this by the group too. Does that help? If not, happy to jump on a call.
